title: A piece of cake: Historic Tea Room owners lose Block Arcade dispute
text:
The husband-and-wife operators of Melbourne's most famous and oldest cake shop, the Hopetoun Tea Rooms in the renowned The Block Arcade on Collins Street, have lost their three-year legal battle with their wealthy landlord.

Kon and Kelly Koutoumanos, whose decadent cake displays draw daily queues of tourists eager to experience the cafe's old world charm, face the prospect of having to pay almost $1.5 million to the owners of the 130-year-old arcade, the Cohen family, who lent them money in 2016 to finance a failed restaurant venture in the basement below the tea rooms.

Kelly Koutoumanos, owner of Hopetoun Tea Rooms in the Block Arcade. Luis Enrique Ascui

In his findings, Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal (VCAT) senior member Rohan Walker criticised the evidence given by the Koutoumanoses, noting Kon Koutoumanos' "untruthful" internet profile (as reported in The Australian Financial Review in March) and that he did "not regard him as being a reliable witness".

“I found some of the actions and decisions taken by Kelly and Kon difficult to understand," Mr Walker also wrote, referring to the couple's decision to "agree to a lease of the basement ... without first having in place sufficient funds to finance the venture".

By contrast, Grant Cohen, manager of the Block Arcade, his father Trevor Cohen and Mrs Cohen were described as "honest witnesses".
description: Hopetoun Tea Room owners Kon and Kelly Koutoumanos will have to pay at least $1.5 million to the Cohen family, owners of the Block Arcade.
